moves.1. e4: It's a very common and very easy to be developed through so many variations. Play as white, I usually start with 1. e2 e4 and hope black doesn't perform Sicilian Defense, I hate that ...
moves.1... e5: A common and a quite good response to 1. e2 e4 ...
moves.2. Nf3: Initiating an attack to black's pawn, I move the knight to f3... (King's Knight Opening, C40)
moves.2... d6: Black move his pawn to d6, starting a strong Philidor's Defence, but here come a new problem. It's very hard to develop his king's bishop...
moves.3. Nc3: Actually an usual response to break Philidor's Defence is moving white pawn to d4, but I want to try something new: moving queen's knight to c3.
moves.3... Bg4:
3. ....... Bg4?
I don't know why black move the bishop to g4, it's very weak... Actually Nc6 is better..
But as long it doesn't threat my king, I let it stand here.
moves.4. Bc4: I move my bishop to c4 to prepare castling, a very common idea for beginner like me.
moves.4... h6: Black move his pawn to h6, maybe he want to stop my knight's movements. Here I see a very good chance to attack black... A queen sacrifice!
moves.5. Nxe5:
5. Nxe5!?
I think it's the most interesting move in this game. Giving my queen to black!
moves.5... Bxd1:
Actually black must think it deeply, because I won't give my queen without any reasons. But, maybe he thought that I make an error or because I am still beginner (the last is right!)

ANALYSIS=
How if black refuse my queen and take my knight at e5? There's no problem. I'll take the g4 bishop and performing a well developed position.
moves.6. Bxf7+:
My bishop do a starting check 6. Bxf7+ !! 
The king has no choices. He just can move to e7 since d7 is guarded by my knight.
moves.6... Ke7: And a very beautiful checkmate that can't be avoided since 5. ..... Bxd1 ??
